slides.title: Welcome to Underwriting Authority
slides.notes: Introduction to the concept of underwriting authority in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Welcome to our exploration of underwriting authority within Guidewire PolicyCenter. In this session, we'll dive into how underwriting authority impacts the policy lifecycle, focusing on the interactions between agents and underwriters. It's crucial for ensuring policies meet a company's risk standards before they're issued or renewed. Let's set the stage for understanding these interactions and how they tie into the broader PolicyCenter data model.
slides.ocrText: Introduction to Underwriting Authority

slides.title: The Role of Underwriting
slides.notes: Understanding how underwriting fits into the insurance process.
slides.narration: Underwriting plays a pivotal role in the insurance process by assessing risk and determining policy terms. In PolicyCenter, this involves evaluating data such as applicant details and policy specifics to decide on coverage options. You'll often interact with entities like PolicyPeriod and related policy line items, which provide the necessary data for underwriting decisions. This sets the foundation for understanding how authority levels are assigned and managed.
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

• Explain the concepts of Underwriting Authority
* Describe Underwriting Issues

slides.title: Underwriting Authority in PolicyCenter
slides.notes: Overview of how underwriting authority is represented in the system.
slides.narration: In PolicyCenter, underwriting authority is not just a concept; it's implemented as part of the system's configuration. This authority determines who can approve certain underwriting decisions and is often tied to roles and permissions defined within the application. As a developer, you'll configure these authorities to ensure that the right level of approval is required for different underwriting issues, reflecting your organization's risk management policies.
slides.ocrText:
Darren
Insurance
Product Manager

Underwriting is a very important aspect of our
business. Most people in our industry need to
understand the basics around underwriting authority
in the application. How does it work?

slides.title: Underwriting Process Flow
slides.originalNotes:
Underwriting process
An agent or a producer creates a policy using the submission transaction. If the policy has an issue that blocks quoting, the agent cannot view the quote until the undewriter approves the issue and releases the policy back to the agent. Once the underwriter approves the issue, then the agent can view the quote, then bind and issue the policy, or the agent can edit the policy which potentially raises new issues. The new issues will have to go through the underwriting process agaim
slides.notes:
Underwriting process
An agent or a producer creates a policy using the submission transaction. If the policy has an issue that blocks quoting, the agent cannot view the quote until the undewriter approves the issue and releases the policy back to the agent. Once the underwriter approves the issue, then the agent can view the quote, then bind and issue the policy, or the agent can edit the policy which potentially raises new issues. The new issues will have to go through the underwriting process agaim
slides.narration: Let's walk through the underwriting process flow in PolicyCenter, starting with the creation of a policy using a submission transaction. If a policy issue arises that blocks quoting, the agent must wait for underwriter approval before proceeding. This ensures that any risk concerns are addressed early. Once approved, the agent can view the quote and decide to bind and issue the policy. However, any policy edits might introduce new issues, requiring another round of underwriting. This iterative process ensures compliance with underwriting standards.

slides.title: Configuring Underwriting Authority
slides.originalNotes:
Underwriting authority
The details on how to configure the undewriting authority will be covered in the Configuring Undenvriting Authority module in the Po/icyCenter Configuration Guide course.
slides.notes:
Underwriting authority
The details on how to configure the undewriting authority will be covered in the Configuring Undenvriting Authority module in the Po/icyCenter Configuration Guide course.
slides.narration: Configuring underwriting authority in PolicyCenter is a critical task that aligns with your organization's risk management framework. While we'll delve deeper into this configuration in a dedicated module, it's important to understand that it involves setting roles, permissions, and approval levels. This configuration ensures that decisions are made by the right personnel with the appropriate oversight, maintaining the integrity of the underwriting process.
slides.ocrText:
| Underwriting authority Gi

• Provides underwriting rules and an underwriting infrastructure to manage
underwriting issues

• Major components
« Underwriting Issue — A specific occurrence on a policy transaction where an underwriting
condition was true.

« Underwriting Rule — Describes how the policy transaction is affected by underwriting issues
and how issues can be approved. The rules include the conditions which will raise an
underwriting issue.

• Authority Grant — The ability to approve underwriting issues and to what degree.

• Authority Profile — A group of authorities that can be given to a user, allowing the user to
approve underwriting issues.

slides.title: Handling Underwriting Issues
slides.originalNotes:
Underwriting issues
There are certain issues that can be approved by agents, but certain issues need special approval from underwriters. Forexample, if the driver or applicant has a suspended/revoked license, then the agent cannot quote the policy and an underwriting issue is raised and sent to the underwriter for approval. However, if a driver is driving a vehicle garaged in CA but has a valid MA driver’s license, then the agents canverify the license and an underwriting issue will not be raised. PolicyCenter raises issues automatically based on policy choices such as vehicles types on a policy or coverage amounts.
slides.notes:
Underwriting issues
There are certain issues that can be approved by agents, but certain issues need special approval from underwriters. Forexample, if the driver or applicant has a suspended/revoked license, then the agent cannot quote the policy and an underwriting issue is raised and sent to the underwriter for approval. However, if a driver is driving a vehicle garaged in CA but has a valid MA driver’s license, then the agents canverify the license and an underwriting issue will not be raised. PolicyCenter raises issues automatically based on policy choices such as vehicles types on a policy or coverage amounts.
slides.narration: Underwriting issues in PolicyCenter can vary in complexity. Some can be resolved by agents, while others require underwriter intervention. For example, a suspended license will trigger an issue needing underwriter approval, preventing the quote until resolved. PolicyCenter automates issue detection based on predefined rules, reacting to factors like vehicle types or coverage levels. This automation helps streamline operations while ensuring compliance with underwriting guidelines.

slides.title: Understanding Checking Sets
slides.notes: Introduction to checking sets in underwriting rules.
slides.narration: Checking sets are a key component of underwriting rules in PolicyCenter. They determine when the system should evaluate certain conditions. For example, a rule might specify a checking set at the pre-quote stage, triggering an evaluation of whether a policy meets specific criteria before a quote is generated. This proactive approach helps identify potential issues early, allowing for timely resolution and smoother policy processing.
slides.ocrText:
| Creating underwriting issues

« Raised automatically based on policy choices

« UWrules trigger UW issues
+ Rule conditions can be created in the UW rule user interfaces

+ More complex conditions can be written in Gosu code
« Automatically removed when the condition is resolved
* Can be added manually on the UW Issues screen

* Manual issues are not removed automatically

slides.title: The Role of Checking Sets
slides.originalNotes:
Checking set
A checking set is one of the important fields in underwriting rules. It works together with the blocking point, which is discussed in detail on the next slide. For example, the underwriting rule for high-value vehicles has a checking set as pre-quote. When a quote is requested, it checks if this issue exists. Ifthe issueexists, it raises a high-value vehicle underwriting issue at quote time. The rule has a blocking point as a bind, so a premium is generated and displayed, however, it blocks binds and the issue must be resolved before binding the policy.
slides.notes:
Checking set
A checking set is one of the important fields in underwriting rules. It works together with the blocking point, which is discussed in detail on the next slide. For example, the underwriting rule for high-value vehicles has a checking set as pre-quote. When a quote is requested, it checks if this issue exists. Ifthe issueexists, it raises a high-value vehicle underwriting issue at quote time. The rule has a blocking point as a bind, so a premium is generated and displayed, however, it blocks binds and the issue must be resolved before binding the policy.
slides.narration: Checking sets and blocking points work hand-in-hand within underwriting rules in PolicyCenter. A checking set can be used to flag issues like high-value vehicles during the pre-quote stage. Even if issues are detected, the system can generate a quote, but the bind process is blocked until resolution. This mechanism ensures that policies are scrutinized appropriately before finalization, balancing operational efficiency with risk management.
slides.ocrText:
| Checking set

•« Achecking set represents a point in a job where issues can be raised
* pre-quote
* bind
* pre-issuance, etc.

• Used to specify when to check if an issue exists

slides.title: Understanding Blocking Points
slides.originalNotes:
Blocking point
Users define a blocking point for each underwriting rule. For example, PolicyCenter prevents a user from binding a policy until a high-value vehicle underwriting issue is approved.

Blocking points can be set to non-blocking so that an issue does not stop the job, but shows up as an informational issue on the Risk Analysis page as shown in the slide. When the underwriting issue is informational, the agent can progress further in the job and quote, bind and issue the policy. Informational issues do not need underwriter approval.

Note: Issues can be detected early, but then block at a much later point. For example, you can detect fire-breathing clowns before quoting a policy, but the issue will block binding.
By detecting issues early, you can provide added visibility to PolicyCenter users, and improve their ability to plan their work.
Detect issues as early as possible and think carefullyabout where they will block progress.
If a field were only available on a quote screen (e.g. manual pricing adjustment factor), but its value blocked the quote, it would result in you not being able to return to the earlier screen to implement changes.
slides.notes:
Blocking point
Users define a blocking point for each underwriting rule. For example, PolicyCenter prevents a user from binding a policy until a high-value vehicle underwriting issue is approved.

Blocking points can be set to non-blocking so that an issue does not stop the job, but shows up as an informational issue on the Risk Analysis page as shown in the slide. When the underwriting issue is informational, the agent can progress further in the job and quote, bind and issue the policy. Informational issues do not need underwriter approval.

Note: Issues can be detected early, but then block at a much later point. For example, you can detect fire-breathing clowns before quoting a policy, but the issue will block binding.
By detecting issues early, you can provide added visibility to PolicyCenter users, and improve their ability to plan their work.
Detect issues as early as possible and think carefullyabout where they will block progress.
If a field were only available on a quote screen (e.g. manual pricing adjustment factor), but its value blocked the quote, it would result in you not being able to return to the earlier screen to implement changes.
slides.narration: Blocking points in underwriting rules dictate when a detected issue prevents further progress in a policy transaction. This could be at the quote or bind stage, depending on the rule configuration. Sometimes, issues are flagged as informational, allowing the process to continue while highlighting potential risks. As developers, understanding how and when to set blocking points is crucial, as it directly impacts policy workflow and user experience. Early detection of issues allows agents to plan and address these concerns proactively, ensuring smoother policy management.

slides.title: Underwriting Authority: Practical Considerations
slides.notes: Discuss practical considerations when implementing underwriting authority.
slides.narration: When implementing underwriting authority in PolicyCenter, consider the practical aspects like role-based access and alignment with organizational policies. It's vital to ensure that authority levels match the complexity and risk associated with different policy types. This not only ensures compliance but also empowers agents to make decisions within their scope, streamlining the approval process and enhancing operational efficiency.

Notice how these settings align with the roles defined in your organization, providing a structured approach to managing underwriting approvals. This demonstration will highlight the user experience aspect of underwriting authority management.

slides.title: Configuring Underwriting Rules
slides.notes: Overview of configuring underwriting rules in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Configuring underwriting rules in PolicyCenter is where your understanding of the data model becomes crucial. These rules are defined based on policy attributes and risk factors, using entities like PolicyLine and Coverage. The configuration involves setting conditions and actions that guide the system's decision-making process, ensuring that policies adhere to underwriting guidelines while automating routine checks.

questionData.question: When is an undermnriting issue raised?
questionData.answer: Underwriting issues are raised when policy choices meet the conditions defined in the underwriting rules or Gosu code. In certain situations, underwriters can add issues manually depending on their permissions. Sooo ooo ooo Oooo oOoD

slides.title: Data Model Considerations
slides.notes: Exploring the data model entities related to underwriting authority.
slides.narration: Understanding the data model is critical when dealing with underwriting authority in PolicyCenter. Key entities include PolicyPeriod, UnderwritingIssue, and UserRole, each playing a distinct part in defining and managing authority levels. Familiarity with these entities allows you to effectively configure and customize the system to meet specific business needs, ensuring that data integrity and process efficiency are maintained.

slides.notes: Identifying integration points within PolicyCenter for underwriting authority.
slides.narration: Underwriting authority doesn't exist in isolation; it often requires integration with other systems and modules within Guidewire. Consider how data flows between PolicyCenter and external systems like claims or billing, ensuring that underwriting decisions are informed by the latest data. Identifying these integration points is crucial for maintaining consistency and accuracy across the insurance suite, enhancing the overall decision-making process.

slides.title: Customizing Underwriting Workflows
slides.notes: Discussing customization options for underwriting workflows in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Customizing underwriting workflows in PolicyCenter allows you to tailor the system to meet specific business requirements. Whether it's adjusting approval thresholds or modifying notification settings, these customizations ensure that the underwriting process aligns with your company's operational goals. Leveraging Gosu scripts and PCF configurations, you can enhance the system's flexibility and responsiveness, providing a competitive edge in policy management.

slides.title: Best Practices for Managing Underwriting Authority
slides.notes: Highlight best practices in managing underwriting authority in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Managing underwriting authority effectively requires adhering to best practices. This includes regularly reviewing and updating authority levels, ensuring alignment with current business policies, and facilitating continuous training for underwriters and agents. By maintaining clear documentation and utilizing PolicyCenter's built-in tools, you can ensure that the authority management process remains transparent, efficient, and adaptable to changing market conditions.

slides.title: Common Challenges and Solutions
slides.notes: Address common challenges in implementing underwriting authority and their solutions.
slides.narration: Implementing underwriting authority can present challenges such as managing complex approval hierarchies and ensuring data accuracy. Solutions involve leveraging PolicyCenter's rule engine to automate decision-making and employing robust data validation techniques. By anticipating these challenges and planning accordingly, you can streamline the authority management process and minimize disruptions to policy operations.
